G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this Honorable Court issued the original custody order dated April 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this Honorable Court issued the original custody order dated April 15, 2018.

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996) ("The overriding principle in determining modification of custody is the best interests of the child.").
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: The material changes outlined in this Complaint warrant modification of the April 15, 2018, order in accordance with the child’s current needs and circumstances. See Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996) ("The overriding principle in determining modification of custody is the best interests of the child.").
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in modifying custody under G.L. c. 208, § 28, the governing standard is whether the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children, and it discusses this in the context of a material and substantial change in circumstances. The user’s proposition—that material changes warrant modification of an existing order in accordance with the child’s current needs and circumstances—is consistent with this best-interests-and-change-of-circumstances framework. Thus, the case is an appropriate authority for that proposition.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 28, as amended through St. 1993, c. 460, enables a Probate Court judge, upon finding that “a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred” to modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody arrangements of minor children, where the modification “is necessary in the best interests of the children.” … When determining child custody awards in general, or modifications of custody awards based on changed circumstances, the guiding principle always has been the best interests of the children.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)..proposition: In making custody determinations, Massachusetts courts consider factors such as the child’s physical, psychological, and emotional development. See Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)..support_reasoning: The court repeatedly frames the removal/custody determination in terms of the children’s “best interests,” expressly noting that this standard is grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child. In applying that standard, the opinion discusses the child’s learning disability, socialization needs, emotional harm from family conflict, and the developmental disruption posed by relocation, thereby showing that Massachusetts courts consider children’s physical, psychological, educational, and emotional development when making such determinations.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006)..relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). … The judge concluded that, in light of the disruptions to his developmental process that would be occasioned by the challenges of a new home, school, and sibling, and reduction in the time spent with the father, the move to New Hampshire would be ‘detrimental’ to the older child’s socialization and education.”

Middleton v. Middleton, 69 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Middleton v. Middleton, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (2007);
Middleton v. Middleton, 69 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: Massachusetts case law establishes that stability, continuity, and a child’s expressed preferences are key considerations in determining child custody arrangements. See Middleton v. Middleton, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (2007); Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).

Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).proposition: Massachusetts case law establishes that stability, continuity, and a child’s expressed preferences are key considerations in determining child custody arrangements. See Middleton v. Middleton, 69 Mass. App. Ct. 1109 (2007); Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on procedural issues and, on the merits, solely on whether parties in a custody proceeding have the right to cross‑examine a guardian ad litem whose report is considered by the judge. While it briefly reiterates that the controlling standard in custody matters is the child’s “best interests,” it does not discuss stability, continuity, or the child’s expressed preferences as distinct or key considerations in custody determinations. Thus, it does not substantively support the specific proposition for which it is cited.
Gilmore v. Gilmore, 369 Mass. 598 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “We are mindful of the court’s need for assistance in arriving at a just resolution of custody cases. There is no question that court-appointed investigators can help a judge to determine what is in the best interests of a child, ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided.’ Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930).”

Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.raw_text: Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.proposition: Courts also recognize that a parent’s improved living conditions may constitute a material change warranting modification. See Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 (2006).
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal case, not a general custody/visitation modification case based on improved living conditions. Its discussion of “material and substantial change in circumstances” focuses on the mother’s remarriage as such a change, not on improved housing, financial, or general living conditions as a basis for modification. Nowhere does the court state or imply that improved living conditions of a parent, by themselves, constitute a material change warranting modification, so the proposition over-reads the case’s holding.
Pizzino v. Miller, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865.relevant_excerpt: “In the present case, the mother’s marriage is plainly a material and substantial change in circumstances occurring subsequent to the date of divorce. The judge’s contrary treatment contributed to his devaluation of the mother’s marriage as a factor to be considered, and may well have had a significant effect on his over-all treatment of the case.”

D.A. v. T.R., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 141 (200.raw_text: D.A. v. T.R., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 141 (2008).
D.A. v. T.R., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 141 (200.proposition: A visitation schedule that interferes with a child’s education or disrupts a child’s daily routine is not in the child’s best interests. See D.A. v. T.R., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 141 (2008).
D.A. v. T.R., 73 Mass. App. Ct. 141 (200.support_reasoning: This opinion is a fee dispute/malpractice case between attorneys and former clients and does not involve custody, visitation, or any issue concerning a child’s education or daily routine. Nowhere does the court discuss visitation schedules or best interests of a child. The cited case therefore does not provide authority for the proposition about visitation interfering with education or routine.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: The proposed modification adheres to the principles established in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985), by supporting the minor child’s best interests and ensuring his welfare and stability.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: Yannas squarely addresses removal of a minor child by the custodial parent and articulates the governing standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30: removal is permissible when, upon cause shown, it is in the child’s best interests, evaluated through the ‘real advantage’ to the custodial parent and the resulting impact on the child’s welfare and stability. The court emphasizes that the child’s best interests remain paramount and must be assessed holistically, including the quality and stability of life with the custodial parent and the preservation of a meaningful relationship with the noncustodial parent. This aligns with the proposition that a modification allowing relocation must support the child’s best interests and ensure welfare and stability under Yannas.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these “best interests” are to be determined. . . . An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life) . . . and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.
